children.subject:
You don't REALLY need to take CS 170. The most important topics covered in 170 are graphs, dynamic programming, linear programming, time complexity, and NP-completeness. 

Of these topics, for interviews, dynamic programming, graphs, and analysis of runtime can be useful, but nothing you can't study (61B goes over some graphs, DP is just another way to look at recursion, runtime also 61B). 

For the actual workforce, it will depend on what you're doing, but you only really need to keep in mind time complexity. The other topics are really more useful in more theoretical aspects of EE/CS. 

Furthermore, the class itself isnt as much focused on topics as it is the APPROACH to solving problems with clever/neat algorithms (which can be useful in interviews).

history.content: I'm CS major pressed for time to graduate so I'm taking lighter load CS upper division courses and electives. If I graduate in the summer I will not have taken CS170 by the time I graduate. How much of a disadvantage will I be in the workforce if I have not taken CS170? Is it really as necessary and helpful as people make it out to be? I imagine it's not anything you can't self-study on your own.
history.subject: Graduating without CS170
